text: When I enter a social situation, I notice my breathing and slow it down before anxiety takes over.
During conversations, I stay present and listen instead of scanning for judgment or criticism.
When I feel self-conscious, I notice the feeling and choose to focus on the other person instead.
I let fear of embarrassment or judgment stop me from speaking or participating in social moments.
When my body feels tense in social settings, I breathe slowly and ground myself in the present moment.
I recognize when my mind is overthinking what others might be thinking, and I redirect my attention outward.
When I notice the urge to avoid or leave a social situation, I pause and choose to stay present instead.
I let worries about how I look or sound control my behavior and drain my confidence.
When I feel the pull to analyze every word I said, I notice the pattern and let the thoughts drift away.
I see when my mind is imagining worst-case scenarios, and I choose a simpler, more realistic interpretation.
When I sense physical symptoms like sweating or trembling, I breathe and stay steady instead of reacting to them.
I let fear of being judged or evaluated prevent me from expressing myself or joining conversations.
When I notice myself scanning the room for signs of judgment, I redirect my focus to the conversation itself.
I recognize when my inner critic is speaking, and I choose to respond with self-compassion instead.
When I feel the urge to rehearse what I'll say, I notice the pressure and choose to speak naturally instead.
I let social anxiety drive me to avoid situations or isolate myself from others.
When I sense the old pattern of fear rising, I pause and remind myself that I can handle this moment.
I notice when my mind is comparing myself to others, and I choose to focus on connection instead.
When I feel the pull to overthink a past interaction, I recognize it as the pattern and let it go.
I let fear of embarrassment or humiliation control my choices and limit my social experiences.
